title: 108_hr2630
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commercial Alien Smuggling Elimination Act of 2003" or the "CASE Act of 2003." It introduces a new class of nonimmigrant aliens. The "Commercial Alien Smuggling Elimination Act of 2003" introduces a new class of nonimmigrant aliens under Section 101(a)(15)(S) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. This amendment allows individuals with critical reliable information on alien smuggling organizations to stay in the United States if they provide or are willing to provide such information to a court. The "Commercial Alien Smuggling Elimination Act of 2003" introduces a new class of nonimmigrant aliens under Section 101(a)(15)(S) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. This amendment allows individuals with critical reliable information on alien smuggling organizations to stay in the United States if deemed essential for authorized criminal investigations, prosecution, or disruption of such organizations. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to limit the number of nonimmigrant visas under section 101(a)(15)(S)(iii) to 400 per fiscal year. Additionally, officials are authorized to take necessary actions to protect the identity of nonimmigrants and their family members under this section. SEC. 3. Adjustment of status of nonimmigrant to that of person admitted for permanent residence. Section 245(j) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include provisions for nonimmigrants admitted under specific sections who provide information contributing to alien smuggling investigations or prosecutions. The Secretary of Homeland Security may adjust the status of certain aliens and nonimmigrants to that of lawful permanent residents based on specific criteria. The Attorney General may take lawful action to protect the identity of a person whose status is adjusted under specific criteria. SEC. 4. BRINGING IN AND HARBORING CERTAIN ALIENS. Criminal penalties for bringing aliens into the US in violation of the Immigration and Nationality Act may be increased by up to 10 years if the offense is part of a commercial organization, aliens are transported in groups of 10 or more, and their transport endangers lives. Additionally, a rewards program is established in the Department. A rewards program is established in the Department of Homeland Security to assist in eliminating commercial alien smuggling involving groups of 10 or more aliens in dangerous conditions. The program is administered by the Secretary of Homeland Security in consultation with the Attorney General and the Secretary of State. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Attorney General and the Secretary of State, may pay a reward to individuals providing information leading to the arrest or conviction of those involved in commercial alien smuggling endangering lives or posing health risks in groups of 10 or more aliens. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Attorney General and the Secretary of State, may pay a reward to individuals providing information leading to the arrest or conviction of those involved in commercial alien smuggling endangering lives or posing health risks in groups of 10 or more aliens. This includes aiding or abetting such acts, prevention, resolution, dismantling of smuggling organizations, and identifying key leaders. Authorization of appropriations is provided for necessary funds. The subsection authorizes appropriations for carrying out rewards for individuals providing information on commercial alien smuggling. Government officials furnishing information while on duty are ineligible for rewards. Protection measures can be taken for individuals and their family members providing information. The subsection allows rewards up to $100,000 for information on alien smuggling, with exceptions for larger amounts authorized by the Secretary of Homeland Security in specific cases. Rewards exceeding $50,000 require personal approval by the Secretary of Homeland Security, and any granted reward must be certified for payment by the Secretary. Additionally, an outreach program will be developed to educate the public about these issues. The subsection aims to educate the public about penalties for harboring aliens and incentives for assisting in disrupting smuggling operations in the US and abroad.
